review_blob: It sounded so enticing, turns out slightly disappointing. Aroma is citrus, pine and...soap. The appearance is nice - a hazy gold with think off white head that leaves lacing throughout. Flavor pretty well mirrors the aroma. I was hoping for more hops, even some yeasiness, but I get citrus, resin and soap. A bit heavier palate. I hope for more from their other varieties.

Can you say, booozy? Holy sh**! Aroma is nice; a liquor alcohol burn, but chocolate, anise, charcoal. Appearance is pretty, as I love me a  stout - deep dark chocolate with a mocha head. Head disappears quickly, though, with little lacing. Palate is spicy with the booze, and coats at the same time. Overall - kick you in the pants!!!

Aroma is apple and grass. Appearance is clear and effervesent like a cider. The taste is crisp apple and a bit of yeast. On the palate, its crisp, clean and a bit sparkling. Its tasty. Good thing winter never really showed up in MN because this is a warmer weather beer.

Nice appearance - deep black brown with a reddish tinge. Nice lacing, colorful lacing but mostly dissipates. Aroma is roasty, but sweet - sugar, chocolate syrup, slight honey with notes of tobacco. Light, but still coating the palate. Flavors of chocolate and tobacco, a bit nutty. Decent, nice, but not blowing my socks off.

Pours almost transparent amber with off-white head that leaves nice lacing throughout.  Aroma is strong caramel malt with some fruity citrus and peach, a bit of candi sugar.  Definite bitter hop finish - fruitiness is amplified when it warms.  Im typically a fan of New Zealand hops, so I dig it.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Fresh Hop IPA - Southern Hemisphere

review_blob: Pours light, bright gold with big white head. Aroma is clove, spice and yeast. Big, bready Belgian aroma without the tasts. Flavor is fruity, tropical with just enough sweet maltiness to balance it out and a slightly dry mild hop bitterness.  I am impressed, and saisons continue to grow on me lately. Nice warm weather beer that pairs well with summer food.

Distinctly reminds me of the St. Feuillien/Green Flash collabo.  Pours bright gold, cloudy, with big, pillowy white head.  Smells of yeast, citrus, lemongrass, a bit of pepper spice and bitter hops.  Flavor is a touch sweet candi sugar with heavy lemon citrus, a bit tart, grassy with hops almost seeming to dry it out some on the finish. It smells far more belgian than it tastes. I like the lemon...Im pretty sure I like the beer.  Well have to let it open up a bit.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - Reboot White I.P.A.

review_blob: Pours brown-black with big, pillowy tan head. Smells pretty delicious; some citrusy hops with a bit of chocolate and tobacco. Flavors fall a bit short - good malt bill with orange citrus, not quite fitting together. Very thin and a bit flat on the palate.  Just didnt quite all come together.

Pours hazy, light gold with very thin white head. Aroma is lemon citrus, faint peach and bubblegum. Flavors are similar; bread, citrus, light peach with a bit of spicy hops to give some dryness to the finish. Thin on the palate. A nice surprise.

Pours deep, firey amber with thin off-white head. Looks to pretty heavily cling to the glass when swirled/agitated, but lacing doesnt stick. Aroma is big malty caramel, some semblance of a barleywine, pine and stone fruit, also a bit boozy. A bit thick on the palate. Flavor is sticky resin, heavy bitter hops, a nice malty sweet balance, some alcohol but masked decently for 12%. I hoppy big beer....good stuff. Enjoyed it as much as last years, but maybe Ill hang on to one or two for a bit this time to see how it develops.

Pours amber with thick cream head. Leaves a nice lacing, but not too sticky. Aroma is floral hops, yeast and spicy herbal notes. Flavor is peppery, fennel, a bit of toffee sweetness and a dryer floral hop finish. Nice, medium body with light carbonation. In line with the others in the Hatter series....nothing spectaular, but drinkable.

Pours brown-black with 2 finger thick cream head. Nice, sticky lacing throughout. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, faint coffee and a tinge of hoppy bitterness. Flavor is caramel malt sweetness up front with some piney hops balancing it out. Decent, but Ive had better black IPAs.

Pours deep copper with not much of an off white head. Aroma is a bit woody, slight bourbon and charcoal. Very thin body. Tastes a bit watered down. Hard to discern oak, but maybe detecting a bit of sweetness from it. Faint bourbon flavor and a little hop bitterness, but overall falls severely short.
beer_name: New Holland Oak Aged Hatter IPA

review_blob: Pours hazy gold, with thin white head. Aroma is piney, resinous with sweet maltiness. Flavor is floral, pine, bitter hops. Pretty average. Not feeling this one.

Pours thick, dark plum. Almost looks like a fruit syrup in the glass. Aroma is belgian yeast, raspberriew, cherries and just plain old sugar. Flavor is sweet raspberry jam with a yeastiness and almost dry finish. Pretty full bodied and very little carbonation. A nice little aperitif.

Pours translucent gold with just a slight cream head, vanishing. Aroma is bold, fruity, malty, sweet. Flavor is peach, resinous hop bitterness with a bit of spice and yeast on the finish. Medium body does coat the mouth a little. Overall, nice flavorful kick.
Pours black brown with very thin cream head. Aroma is big, roasty malt, nutty, toffee. Flavors are cocoa, caramel, with some earthy hop bitterness on the finish. Very drinkable.

Pours amber with very little head. Aroma is caramel, citrus and pine. Flavor is bitter, resinous hops with a lemony bite and slight malty sweetness for a little more balance. Not heavy on the palate at all, pretty bitter hops. Probably couldnt drink a few in one sitting.

Pours reddish-orange with thin off white head, leaves nice lacing. Aroma is bread, banana, faint resinous hops and caramel malt. Flavor is deep, but not overpowering. Sweet up front with caramel, some piney hop bitterness and creamy mouthfeel. Very drinkable.

Pours almost transparent gold. Thin head, quickly diminishes. Aroma is relatively faint - caramel malt sweetness, citrus, orange, a bit grassy. Flavor is more malty than hoppy, not quite what I was expecting. Not necessarily a bad thing. Mixed feelings right now.

Pours light, bright straw color with a big pillowy head. Steady carbonation; slight lacing throughout. Aroma is spicy, yeasty, bready, citrus - reminds me a bit of a lemon poppyseed muffin - still a hint of funk, earth, grass. Taste is peppered, grassy, floral hops with a slight brett tartneess on the finish. Relatively light on the palate with nice carbonation and lingering finish.

Pours reddish brown with big, fluffy off white head. Aroma is a bit earthy, funk, caramel malt, dried cherries. Flavor is delish - toffee sweetness leading into caramel, green apple tartness, nice acidity with a similar malty sweet finish. A nice pairing to the passionfruit sorbet I was eating, and all around a very nice beer.

Pours hazy gold with frothy, white head and continuous bubbly carbonation. Aroma is sour, funky wild yeast with tart green apple and lemon zest. First taste prompts serious puckering - champagne like effervescence, earthy, oaky, maybe a bit of sour lemon with just a touch of malty sweetness (i think, but very slight) pairing with the very dry finish. Continuously awakening the palate with its bubbling tartness at every sip. Loving wild ales and enjoying this as well.

Kind of disappointing, but may need to revisit. Pours oily black with thin tan head. Aroma is burnt chocolate, a little ashy, slight dried fruit and some alcohol. Also oily on the palate. Flavor is more dark fruits, strong alcohol, with a bit of dark chocolate on the finish. Sadly thinking dinner is negatively affecting this one.
beer_name: Goose Island Big John Imperial Stout

review_blob: Pours hazy yellow-gold decent sized sticky white head. Leaves some nice lacing throughout. Aromas are mild - some floral hops, a little yeast, coriander. Flavor is actually surprisingly intense. Bittersweet, citrusy hops with orange zest, spicy peppercorn and wheat. Nice, crisp carbonation - refreshing.

2011. Pours deceivingly - darker black brown, yet somehow has a transparent appearance. Small, light head that quickly disappears. Really not a bit of lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, spicy with cardamom and clove and a touch smoky. Thankfully for me, the smokiness is not like burnt bacon and campfire...just a light, toasty smoke. Flavors are sweet raisin, caramel malt, I do taste faint peppercorn. Light and crisp on the palate, nice carbonation that cleanses the palate. A very interesting saison.

Pours not-quite-black with average sized tan head. Looks enticing, not overly heavy - medium bodied. Aroma is roasty, chocolat,e a little vanilla and a bit nutty. Flavor is oats and chocolate, a touch of coffee and a slight bitter hop finish. Pretty deece; drink and repeat.

Pours deep chocolate color with 1/2" off white head. No lacing. Aroma is dark chocolate, toffee, smoke. Flavor is tobacco, caramel-chocolate with a slight bitter hop finish. Not an everwhelming smokiness, but still maybe too much for me. Not my first choice. Average, and ok with the fact that it may not be brewed again....

Whoever thinks this isnt a very "wild" ale must be ill. Pours mahogany with  with a thin beige head that leaves just a slight lacing. Smells of lemon-lime and raspberries, a little like Fun Dip, quite funkified with some maltiness. Flavor is tart cherry, pomegranate, candi sugar and malt...maybe caramelly? Pretty light and crisp on the palate. I dig it, sourness and all.

Wow, what is this amazing madness? Nothing short of de-lish.  Pours a beautiful, cloudy light yellow-gold with a HUGE pillow of white head. Nice sticky lacing throughout. Aroma is belgian yeast and candi sugar with grapefuit, honey and a floral touch. Flavor is an a-mah-zing combo of Belgian/American goodness. Fruity, sweet grapefruit hop flavor, followed by yeasty fullness, some Belsgian spice with a drier hop finish. Keeps me guessing, and Im guessing I want more. Yum!
beer_name: xxx St-Feuillien & Green Flash / Bire De LAmiti

review_blob: Crazy interesting, but probably does need to age a bit for the flavors to mellow. Pours reddish brown with thin head, really no lacing. Aroma is cinnamon raisin bread with a tinge of alcohol. Full-bodied, coats the mouth with caramel/molasses flavors. Intense malt, maybe a touch of spice and again a bit of alcohol once it warms. I enjoyed it, but am interested to see what it does with time.

Pours almost transparent gold, with minimal off white head. Nice aroma - bready, citrus, a touch of honey, bitter hops. Flavor is quite hoppy; still some of the bread/biscuit flavor, pine, resin, a bit floral. Long bitter finish. Pretty nice, sessionable IPA.

10 bottle. Pours dark black-brown with thick tan head that leaves decent lacing. Aroma is heavy and inviting: chocolate, vanilla, toffee, roasty with slight citrus hop in the background. Flavors are similar: bitter dark chocolate, some coffee, toffee with a touch of pine and nice citrusy hop finish. Glad I have another bottle.
beer_name: Deschutes Hop in the Dark CDA

review_blob: Pours cloudy orange. Thin, off-white head with virtually no lacing. Aroma is nice big caramel, tropical fruits, resin and some alcohol. Flavor is caramel sweetness with piney hops and bitter orange peel. Palate is medium bodied with long, bitter hop finish. Decent. Havent had Hardcore IPA, but definitely prefer I Beat You.

Pours transparent reddish-orange. Thin head with virtually no lacing. Aroma is floral, resinous, slight oak, a touch of sweetness - maybe vanilla - and some alcohol....almost smells more like gin than hops. Flavor is pretty well balanced. Slight roasty malt, some sweetness, vanilla and spiciness from the oak, resinous hops, a touch of honey with a bit of alcohol burn. Overall, pretty decently balanced and a smooth transition.
beer_name: Great Divide Anniversary Wood Aged Double IPA

review_blob: Pours translucent blood red. Very minimal head. Aroma is mostly cherry, some raspberry and sour funk. Flavor is very tart, sour - some sweetness, light carbonation and of course cherry and raspberry.  Seems to smooth out a bit, possibly from the oak aging. Its decent, but have found other sour/wild ales that far exceed this.

Interesting, not sure how I feel yet. Pours cloudy golden yellow with minimal head. Aroma is bready, yeasty....almost like I pick up aroma of chai. Flavor is citrusy hops, candi sugar, banana, and bready malt. Reminds me of a slightly hoppier Trippel. Torn on how I feel overall. Might need to let it open up a bit more.

Wish this tasted as good as it looked. Pours light orange with tall off white head.  Leaves nice, sticky lacing throughout. Aroma is dull - some orange peel and a bit of caramel maltiness. Mostly tough to pick much up. Flavor is quite flat, too. Not nearly hoppy enough for an IPA. A touch of light citrus up front, malty - almost scotch like - in the middle, and light bitterness on the finish. Nothing at all to get excited about.

Pours brown with some red and orange flecks. Very large, frothy off white head that leaves a few small patches of lacing throughout. Aroma is yeast, bread, orange rind, clove and other spices - feel like I also pick up faint notes of plum. Flavor is bready with dark fruits, some citrus peel and definite spicy notes to it. Liking how it opens up closer to room temp. Would like to compare Local 1, but I enjoyed it.

Pours thick reddish-brown with light cream head that leaves some sticky lacing. Aroma is cinnamon raisin and fruity hard candy with some yeastiness. Flavor is candied figs, a bit bready, cinnamon and clove with some fruitiness on the finish. Slight alcohol warmth also on the finish. Medium bodied. Definite belgian character. A sweet treat.

Pours reddish-brown with decent sized tan head. Leaves some lacing. Aroma isnt very pronounced. Can get hints of chocolate, coffee and a bit of nuttiness. Flavors are similar - again, not strong flavors. Roasty, nutty, cocoa, and some bitter coffee on the finish. Light body. Sadly, after a friend really talked this one up, a bit disappointing. Potential is there, but Im not getting a lot out of it.

Pours deep chocolate brown, almost purplish tones to it. Not as thick as I expected, but definitely dark. Average tan head that really didnt stick around long. Aroma is kind of fruity sweet, nutty(walnuts), coffee, caramel and some alcohol. Flavor mostly follows suit: nutty, roasty, some coffee notes, bittersweet chocolate and raisins. Medium bodied, light carbonation and some alcohol make up the palate. Pretty decent...

Sadly, disappointing. Pours cloudy amber with off-white head. Leaves some lacing. Aroma is the best part of this beer, so too bad the flavors didnt follow suit. Aroma is piney, orange citrus, grapefruit and some malty sweetness. Flavor is flat, bitter, mineral - overall relatively disappointing. Not the worst thing Ive drank, but I usually expect more from Deschutes.
beer_name: Deschutes Red Chair Northwest Pale Ale

review_blob: Pours dark brown with tan head, diminishing quickly. Aroma is roasty, burnt caramel, cocoa, nutmeg and date. Flavor is relatively sweet up front with with the date flavor and some cocoa coming through - notes of tobacco match the roasty maltiness. Finishes on the bitter side. Medium bodied, average carbonation - a flavorful Bock, which is not typically my first choice in style.

Num. Pours translucent amber with frothy off-white head. Beautiful, sticky lacing throughout. Aroma is a bit acetic with cherry and orange rind. Flavor is sour, tannic, cherry and a bit lemony. Pretty light and crisp on the palate. I really dig it.

Pours dark brown with flecks of red. Thin, tan head that doesnt hang around long. Aroma is a bit nutty, honey with a bit of fig. Flavor is caramel malt, a bit roasty but also a bit flat. Some hops come in on the finish, but couldve stood a bit more of a kick to balance it out.  Id go back to it, but it doesnt top my list.
UPDATED: APR 15, 2011

Pours deep, dark chocolate brown with slight tan head.  Diminishes to leave a thin blanket atop the beer throughout.  Some sticky lacing throughout, as well.  Aroma is heavy pine and citrus rind with nutty roasted notes and touch of dark chocolate. Pine aroma overpowers, but a nice swirl brings out the malt nose. Taste of candied nut quickly leads way to resinous, piney hops.  With a rather bitter, though not at all unpleasant finish.  Medium bodied, mildly carbonated and a bold introduction to Stone beers.
beer_name: Stone Sublimely Self Righteous Black IPA

review_blob: Pours hazy orange gold.  Thin almost white head thats gone almost as fast as it appeared. Aroma is sour peaches, ginger, a bit woodsy and something I couldnt quite pinpoint until i read a different review....lychee, definitely. Flavor is peachy and lychee, as well. A bit yeasty and very tart, almost like a Brut....clearly minus the sparkle. Light, crisp, sour, drinkable and good.
beer_name: New Belgium Lips of Faith - Le Terroir

review_blob: Pours hazy amber with small off-white head. Sweet hop, biscuits and honey, cantaloupe and a bit of caramel aroma. Medium bodied with a slight oily texture. Sweet up front with a similar bready biscuit and honey flavor. A decent malt bill leads to a nice, sticky-sweet, hop finish with just enough bitterness.
